title: Administrative Commands Quiz
description: Quiz covering operating systems administrative commands.

questions.text: Which command is used to list running processes in Windows?
questions.explanation: The tasklist command displays a list of currently running processes in Windows.

questions.text: Which command is used to display network configuration information in Windows?
questions.explanation: The ipconfig command displays network configuration information in Windows.

questions.text: The 'ps' command is used to list running processes in Windows.
questions.explanation: The 'ps' command is used to list running processes in Unix-like systems, not Windows.

questions.text: Which command is used to display network connections in both Windows and Linux?
questions.explanation: The netstat command displays network connections in both Windows and Linux.

questions.text: Which command is used to display the routing table in Linux?
questions.explanation: The route command displays the routing table in Linux.

questions.text: The 'ifconfig' command is used to configure network interfaces in Windows.
questions.explanation: The 'ifconfig' command is used to configure network interfaces in Unix-like systems, not Windows.

questions.text: Which command is used to trace the route to a destination in Windows?
questions.explanation: The tracert command traces the route to a destination in Windows.

questions.text: Which command is used to trace the route to a destination in Linux?
questions.explanation: The traceroute command traces the route to a destination in Linux.

questions.text: The 'arp' command is used to display and modify the ARP cache.
questions.explanation: The 'arp' command is used to display and modify entries in the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) cache.

questions.text: Which command is used to display disk space usage in Unix-like systems?
questions.explanation: The df command displays disk space usage in Unix-like systems.

questions.text: Which command is used to display the current working directory in both Windows and Linux?
questions.explanation: The pwd command displays the current working directory in both Windows and Linux.

questions.text: The 'dir' command is used to list directory contents in Linux.
questions.explanation: The 'ls' command is used to list directory contents in Linux, while 'dir' is used in Windows.

questions.text: Which command is used to list directory contents in Windows?
questions.explanation: The dir command lists directory contents in Windows.

questions.text: Which command is used to change the current directory in both Windows and Linux?
questions.explanation: The cd command changes the current directory in both Windows and Linux.

questions.text: The 'grep' command is used to search for patterns in files.
questions.explanation: The 'grep' command is used to search for patterns in files.

questions.text: Which command is used to display the process ID (PID) of running processes in Linux?
questions.explanation: The ps command with the -p option displays the process ID (PID) of running processes in Linux.

questions.text: Which command is used to terminate a process in Linux?
questions.explanation: The kill command is used to terminate a process in Linux.

questions.text: The 'taskkill' command is used to terminate a process in Linux.
questions.explanation: The 'taskkill' command is used to terminate a process in Windows, not Linux.

questions.text: Which command is used to display the amount of free and used memory in Linux?
questions.explanation: The free command displays the amount of free and used memory in Linux.

questions.text: Which command is used to display the kernel version in Linux?
questions.explanation: The uname -r command displays the kernel version in Linux.
